_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Monterey Regional Water Pollution Control Agency (Agency) Regional Treatment Plant (RTP) is located northeast of the City of Marina, in Monterey County, California. Major plant construction took place in the 1980s, with the Salinas Valley Reclamation Project (SVRP) was completed in 1998.

Monterey Regional Treatment Plant (RTP) has developed a risk management program to address the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program requirements (Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) A?Risk Management Plan (RMP)A? 40 CFR A?68).  The facility is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facilityA?s staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using chlorine in the wastewater treatment process. This is a RMP Program 3 facility.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Monterey RTP has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the chlorine wastewater treatment process.  It is Monterey RTPA?s policy to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Chlorine is used in the wastewater treatment process for odor control and disinfection.  Chlorine is supplied in one-ton containers. Containers, evaporators and chlorinators are contained inside a building equipped with a scrubber system.  The maximum quantity of chlorine stored at the RTP at any one time is limited by an administrative procedure to 15 tons.  

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one toxic worst-case analysis has been defined for the chlorine process.  The resul

ts can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.  

Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary
Scenario Description: A realistic toxic alternative release scenarios was modeled utilizing a break in the supply line scenario.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook. 

Off-site Receptors
RMP requirements state that sensitive populations such as schools, hospitals, day-care centers, long-term health care facilities, prisons, residential areas, public use parks/recreational areas, and major commercial facilities, located within the A?at riskA? area must be identified.  These sensitive populations include individuals who could not remove themselves from the exposure area without assistance. 

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the Monterey RTP has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an chlorine release:
- The system has alarms 
- The system has scrubbers in place and interlocks
- Exhaust gases from the chlorine building can be routed to the scrubber during an emergency.
-Gas detectors
-The system has relief valves and rupture discs
-Emergency air supply
-Emergency power

-Enclosure and neutralization mitigation systems


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by Monterey RTP to manage process safety issues associated with the use of Chlorine for wastewater treatment.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  As chlorine is A?self alarmingA? due to its pungent odor, even minor releases are readily noticeable.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:
- Process Safety Information
- Process Hazard Analysis
- Operating Procedures
- Training
- Mechanical Integrity
- Management of Change
- Pre-Startup Safety Review
- Compliance Audits
- Incident Investigation
- Employee Participation
- Hot Work Permit
- Contractors

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no RMP applicable releases of flammable materials at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. The MRWPCA has developed an Incident Investigation procedure to investigate any major incident or accident that does occur. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Monterey RTP has filed a Chemical Inventory Business Emergency Plan with the Monterey County Fire Department and this plan includes:
- Emergency Alarm Procedures
- Evacuation Procedures
- Safety and Health Considerations
- Notification Procedures
